Award.AwardTitle: EAGER-DynamicData: Collaborative: Exploiting the Dynamically Architectural Configurability for Compressed Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sensors or sensing systems are increasingly critical in a variety of applications including national security, surveillance monitoring and health care. Those systems should function with minimal hardware recourses, minimal communications and minimal computation overhead, and these efficiencies can dramatically improve the performance, reliability and usability, which can broaden the overall application scope of sensor systems. This EAGER project is to pursue preliminary results of dynamic configurability of architectural and circuit models in sensing systems, and the proposed research will have significant impacts on a range of sensing applications under the resource-constrained environment. For example, in large-scale sensor networks or implantable sensors, energy is tightly constrained. The ultimate goal of the research is to exploit the configurability and dynamics of sensing systems to improve the overall system efficiency. This project serves as an expedition to investigate the dynamically architectural sensing techniques and may open a new research direction of theory and practice in the signal acquisition. Upon the success of this project, a better performance-energy tradeoff in the sensing system will be obtained, which can further strengthen its advantage compared to other sampling techniques, and extend its application regime. To broaden the impacts of this project, PIs will disseminate the research results through multiple channels, including conference presentation, journal publication and open research material online. PIs also plan to integrate the research outcomes into the curriculum development and develop a new research seminar on related topics. The project will provide research opportunities for undergraduate students and researchers from underrepresented groups.

Specifically, this EAGER project investigates the dynamic configurability of parameterized Compressed Sensing architecture. With the physical and architectural models, the Compressed Sensing architecture is flexible and provides a larger design/configuration space, and can adapt towards different signal structures and use conditions. The research work is expected to explore a deeper bound of the performance-energy by exploiting the architectural configurability with physical models. To this aim, a set of research tasks will be performed in this project, and the technical thrusts can be summarized from three aspects. First, the project will explore the configurability at both architectural- and circuit- levels in Compressed Sensing, incorporating signal structure variations. Multiple factors in the Compressed Sensing will be investigated. Second, by integrating physical models into the Compressed Sensing architecture, a larger design space will be discovered and defined. The benefit of the performance-energy trade-off will be demonstrated in the new space. Third, a set of novel algorithms will be developed for efficient configuration search in the design space. Several deterministic and heuristic strategies will be investigated in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wearable system is emerging in recent years with technology development on sensing modality, embedding system and computing theory. Equipped with the hot artificial intelligence capability, miniature and intelligent wearable system can even advance to the leading-edge healthcare applications, such as telemedicine, patient rehabilitation and chronic disease analysis. However, the biggest challenging problem for wearable system is the energy-efficiency issue for user experience in these applications. Huge volume sensing biodata and intensive bioevent analysis drain the battery storage rapidly in the sensor node. The short lifetime of the wearable sensors not only increases the recharging trouble for the users, but also suffers from the risk of impairing biodata integrity. Therefore, energy-efficiency of wearable sensor node needs to be tackled in urgent. With more energy savings, the lifetime of wearable system can be prolonged to reduce the recharging trouble. Better energy-efficiency can even improve the form factor of wearable nodes.

To address this energy-efficiency challenge, in this project, we have studied a holistic compressed sensing (CS) based framework to jointly optimize the sensing architecture and computing architecture for wearable system. Specifically, for the sensing architecture, we design the approach from three aspects, including parameter agility, information screen and signal dynamics, to exploit the opportunity of energy savings. We reveal that the circuit-level design freedom is an ignored yet significant factor in the practical CS architecture. The circuit-level parameter, collaborating with traditional architecture parameters, can explore better trade-off between energy and performance with the help of our proposed time-efficient design space exploration algorithm. Besides the opportunities from parameter agility, we also investigate the information screening technique, which is an effective method to reduce data redundancy. In the healthcare-related applications, meaningful bioevents are always on a low duty-cycle. We develop a coarse-to-fine grained and hardware-friendly information screening architecture to filter out the low-effort data analysis task in the sensor node end, which can avoid the unnecessary energy-hungry wireless transmission. Data dynamics is another significant energy consumer for the sensing. The inaccurate controlling of system modules will induce large amount of energy wasting. We investigate a machine learning-based dynamic knob design to enable the sensing architecture adapt to the challenging data dynamics. To further reduce the overhead from the knob, we apply dynamic programming algorithm to exploit the optimal layout of knob taking both accuracy and energy into account. Finally, we squeeze energy savings from the computing perspective of the intelligent analysis capability. Different from conventional “design as a whole” concept, we propose “cross-end” architecture to break the computation into fine-grained functional cells and implement them across the both sensor node end and data aggregator end in wearable system. Our graph theory based formulation can explore the optimal partition layout of functional cells in the cross-end architecture. One surprising finding is our cross-end can improve both energy efficiency and time efficiency simultaneously for the entire wearable system. In addition, this project also trained two Ph.D. students, including one female student.
